entry.title: Disable NetworkManager in CentOS 6
entry.content:
Stop Network Manager Service

# service NetworkManager stop

Disable NetworkManager on boot

# chkconfig NetworkManager off

Enable network service

# chkconfig network on

Start network service

# service network start

Now, use configuration files in /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts to configure your network interfaces.

entry.title: LVM Snapshots Quickie
entry.content:
• Create snapshot

    lvcreate –size 1G –snapshot –name snap /dev/vg0/lvol1

  • Remove snapshot

    lvremove /dev/vg0/snap

After creating the snapshot, can use pvs and lvdisplay to show status. Mount the snapshot the same as any other logical volume. If the snapshot becomes full, it is automatically disabled.

References:

  • Taking a Backup Using Snapshots

  • CentOS Cluster Logical Volume Manager

It’s important to read the man page or other local help documents before running these commands. The documentation referenced doesn’t do a great job of explaining what’s going on.

entry.title: CentOS Network Configuration
entry.content:
This post is mostly being made for me personal notes, but maybe it will assist others at some point. I’m always forgetting the various configuration files involved with setting up networking on a CentOS host. I have decided to document the process I go through each time to help me remember in the future. Most of this information comes from various forums, CentOS documentation and the man pages. If you see something wrong, or a better way to do this, please comment.

/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0 Device specific information:

For DHCP DEVICE=eth0 BOOTPROTO=dhcp ONBOOT=yes

For fixed / static address DEVICE=eth0 BOOTPROTO=none ONBOOT=yes NETWORK=172.24.1.0 NETMASK=255.255.255.0 IPADDR=172.24.1.10

/etc/sysconfig/network System wide networking information:

NETWORKING=yes HOSTNAME=server.example.com GATEWAY=172.24.1.1

/etc/resolv.conf DNS server information

nameserver 8.8.8.8 nameserver 8.8.4.4

After all is set, $service network restart

entry.title: Linux IPv6 Neighbor Discovery
entry.content:
Using ping6 and ip neigh it’s possible to discover other IPv6 hosts on your local network using the link-local addresses. First, use ping6 to ping all hosts on the local network using the IPv6 link-local address

ping6 -c 2 -I eth0 ff02::1

Then, use ip neigh to show a list of IPv6 enable hosts on the local network

ip -f inet6 neigh

entry.title: Why Use ZFS With FreeNAS?
entry.content: I recently started using FreeNAS again after exploring other options that existed, such as openfiler, and now that I’ve returned, ZFS seems to be the cool thing to do.  After reading, watching videos and playing with ZFS I’m sold on all the features it offers.  However, I must ask, is there a compelling reason to use ZFS over UFS for a single disk?  I’d really like to see some comments on this.
